Award.AwardTitle: ABI Innovation: Predicting the combined impact of multiple mutations on protein functional adaptation
Award.AbstractNarration:
An award is made to Johns Hopkins University to develop a new method to model higher order mutation interactions, by combining evolutionary genetics, network models, and protein sequence analysis. The study of how the effects of individual mutations combine to impact the overall function of a protein is a key question in evolutionary biology. It is also a very difficult question, as the effects multiple protein mutations can combine non-additively. In this case, higher order interactions (beyond pairwise) between mutations need to be considered, and the number of interactions increases exponentially as a function of the total number of protein mutations involved. Therefore, if a model?s parameters are mutation interactions, these parameters will far exceed the number of possible experimental observations needed to determine them. As a result, existing bioinformatics methods are limited in their exploration of higher-order evolutionary interactions. Specifically, detailed modeling of how protein mutations combine as steps in the evolutionary path of a protein toward new function is currently lacking. In this project, systematic evolutionary analysis of protein sequence will be conducted to ensure that only residue positions most relevant for evolving new functions are considered. Next, mutated positions will be linked together in a network model. This modeling framework dramatically reduces the number of modeling parameters and incorporates higher order interactions in a tractable fashion. Because nodes in the network correspond to mutated protein positions, any complex combination of mutations can be represented as a path through the network. Using graph theory, metrics will be developed to assess the relationship between path importance within the network and the successful adaptation of a protein to its environment. This work focuses on a simple biological model system -- the evolution antibiotic resistance by the enzyme TEM beta-lactamase in Escherichia coli bacteria. In this system, there is a direct correlation between the evolution of a new function (antibiotic resistance) and survival at the level of the whole organism (bacterial growth). Computational predictions will be systematically tested by introducing mutations of interest into bacterial cultures and measuring survival under exposure to a given antibiotic.

This work promotes close interaction between the computational sciences and biology communities: It combines expertise in computational/statistical modeling of mutations in proteins and applied evolutionary genetics in microbial systems. The broader use of this work will be to anticipate the emergence of drug resistance in clinically relevant proteins. It will also have great utility for protein engineers who seek to design proteins with new or improved functions. Furthermore, it will contribute to the design of therapeutic regimens for diseases driven by bacteria or viruses, in which the evolution of drug resistance is commonplace. The educational goals of the project include new course components for undergraduates and graduates at the universities where the project investigators teach and outreach to underrepresented minority students in science and engineering. More information about the project can be found at: http://karchinlab.org/.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Biological question: Proteins adapt to new environments and acquire new functions, by successive chemical changes (mutations) to their primary structure.  The history of these changes can be modeled as an evolutionary process.  A key and unanswered question in evolutionary biology is how, in response to environmental challenges, mutations combine to impact the overall function of a protein, such as an enzyme's capability to catalyze chemical reactions.  The question is highly relevant for bacterial and viral proteins, which evolve to protect pathogens from drugs designed to kill them. It is also a very difficult question, as the functional contributions of individual mutations are frequently dependent each other; for example, a mutation "X" may have a different effect on protein function if it occurs before a mutation "Y" as opposed to after mutation "Y".  At the same time mutations can be mutually incompatible, which means that the presence of “X” may exclude the presence of “Y” even if “Y” has a strong positive effect on its own.

Approach: We developed new computational models to detect these kinds of dependencies, which provide important insights into how proteins have evolved particular functions and how new functions could evolve in the future.  Our models, which we collectively call "network analysis of protein adaptation" or NAPA, are designed to map complex functional interactions between mutations. Our method systematically analyzes the molecular evolutionary history of a group of functionally related protein sequences. It represents protein evolution as a network model of functionally interacting pairs of mutations. Formal analysis of the topological properties of the network reveals important properties of a protein’s evolution, such as key mutations that enable a protein to adapt to new environmental conditions, or distinct larger groups of functionally interacting mutations.  

Results: As a proof of concept, we tested our computational predictions of the combined effect of mutations in a simple, biological model system -- the evolution of extended spectrum antibiotic resistance by the enzyme TEM β-lactamase in Escherichia coli. In this system, there is a direct correlation between the evolution of a new activity (extended-spectrum resistance) and bacterial survival. Thus, computational predictions can be systematically tested by introducing mutations of interest into bacterial cultures and measuring survival when exposed to extended spectrum antibiotics.  We tested 68 pairs of mutations in TEM β-lactamase, based on NAPA analysis (see Figure 1) and found that the network had considerable value at predicting mutations that together increased antibiotic resistance (accuracy of approximately 70%).

Our team, which consisted of a computational scientist, a microbial geneticist and eleven scientists in training, has applied NAPA to analyze multiple protein families.  We selected families which are rapidly evolving in response to environmental pressures: two bacterial antibiotic resistance enzymes and a non-structural protein from the Zika virus.  We anticipate that NAPA will be useful for generating hypotheses about the adaptive evolution of proteins critical to pathogens’ drug resistance and to design laboratory evolution experiments. The new tools we developed for network analysis of protein adaptation are available as an open source software package at https://github.com/KarchinLab/NAPA.   The package enables pattern visualization as well as mathematical analysis of mutations that are working together to generate new functions.

During the course of our project, we have provided educational materials for high school students via the California State Summer School for Mathematics and Science residential program, and for undergraduate and graduate students in Biomedical Engineering, Computer Science, Applied Mathematics and Statistics, Human Genetics and Chemical Biomolecular Engineering at Johns Hopkins University.  Eleven trainees worked on the project: six graduate students (five from Johns Hopkins and one from U.C. Santa Cruz) and five undergraduate students (four from Johns Hopkins and one from U.C. Santa Cruz). Over the course of the project, the trainees presented five conference talks and seven conference posters, and six of them are co-authors on two papers we are submitting for publication in peer-reviewed journals.  We also worked with engineers from In Silico Solutions, LLC of Falls Church, Virginia, to develop a professional quality version of our software tools.
